title: 109_hr4867
content: The "Puerto Rico Democracy Act of 2006" establishes a federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including an initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. It also addresses applicable laws, requirements, and the availability of funds for the self-determination process. The Congress acknowledges past efforts by Presidents Bush and Clinton to address Puerto Rico's political status through referendums and task forces. President George W. Bush adopted Executive Order 13183, amending it in 2003 to require regular reports on Puerto Rico's status. In 2005, a Task Force recommended a federally sanctioned plebiscite for Puerto Ricans to vote on their territorial status. If Puerto Rico chooses a permanent nonterritorial status, Congress should allow a plebiscite for the people to choose between two options. If Puerto Rico remains a territory, periodic plebiscites should be held to keep Congress informed of the people's wishes. Federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, including initial plebiscite and subsequent procedures. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct a plebiscite in Puerto Rico to choose between continuing territorial status or pursuing a nonterritorial status. Instructions on the ballot will ensure only one option is marked. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years if the majority vote favors continued territorial status. If the majority vote favors permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite will be held with only two options on the ballot. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will conduct plebiscites every 8 years if the majority vote favors continued territorial status. If a majority vote in the first plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, a plebiscite with only two options will be held: statehood or becoming a sovereign nation. Voters must choose one option, and ballots with more than one option marked will not be counted. The plebiscite under subsection (c) must be held during the 111th Congress or by December 31, 2009. If a majority vote in a plebiscite favors permanent nonterritorial status, the next plebiscite must be held within 2 years of the certification of the majority vote. SEC. 4. APPLICABLE LAWS AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS. All Federal laws applicable to the election of the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico also apply to any plebiscite under this Act. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over legal claims related to this Act. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission will issue rules for the plebiscites. Eligible voters under electoral laws can participate in the plebiscites. All eligible voters in Puerto Rico and US citizens born in Puerto Rico can participate in plebiscites. The Puerto Rico State Elections Commission certifies the results to the President and Congress. After the plebiscite in Puerto Rico, the President's Task Force will submit a report to Congress within 6 months, detailing measures to implement the chosen nonterritorial status option. The report will be prepared in consultation with key Puerto Rican officials. During the period from October 1, 2006, until all required plebiscites are completed, up to $5,000,000 from funds allocated to Puerto Rico may be used by the State Elections Commission for plebiscite expenses, including voter education materials approved by the President's Task Force on Puerto Rico's Status.
